I loved this spectacular treat of pure action and adventure.  I have to caution that it's 3 hours long, but it goes by quickly, or watch it streaming in two sittings if you must. It's also got gallons of blood so it's not for the kiddies. It's a fictional story about two real heroes of India's revolution, Raju (Ram Charan) and Bheem (NT Rao Jr), against the British Raj in the 1920s. They never met in real life but the film supposes they did. The two handsome stars become friends not knowing they are on opposite sides. A little girl, Bheem's sister, is kidnapped by the British. While they try to rescue the girl, Bheem falls in love with the governor's niece. And then one has to wonder if the men's friendship can ever survive what befalls them. The action and stunts are astounding, The sets are colorful. The music and choreography excel. You won't be able to get the tunes out of your head. You have to take that leap of faith that two men could have such extraordinary strength. But this story of their friendship and their fight against the Raj as they try to rescue the girl is amazing. RRR supposedly means Rise Revolt and Roar, or else it stands for the initials of the two stars and the director (SS Rajamoulli, the Spielberg of India). There are subtitles. The symbolism abounds, for those knowledgeable of Hindu or Telegu custom, but for me, that went over my head. I loved this anyway. And, those two men can dance!

Sub-titles would have been nice, as the characters all mumble. 6. I didn't like the anti-British aspect, which i think, and hope, was exaggerated, especially the cruelty. Britain could NOT have ruled India all those many decades by being mean to its citizens. 7. The characters are super-natural, which made us think it was either a comedy or a fantasy. The stunts are way over the top with imagination. 8. Disliked all the song and dance scenes--- is this a musical???? Again, too long and confusing. It dragged in the middle, and toward the end I thought it was over. It should have been. Too much. Too many stories, too many characters, too much of everything. I suppose this kind of thing is popular in India and with the counter-culture crowd? I was glad when it finally ended. Sorry, didn't like it. I was rooting for the tigers.

RRR has an amazing score, characters to cheer for, and villains that are despicable. In the big-budget action franchise landscape we're in right now, this was the absolute freshest thing I have seen in a LONG time. Go see this movie.

An alternate history of the Indian struggle for independence, RRR is a histrionic, 3-hour-long extravaganza with absurd — and satisfying — action sequences, motivational twists, and the ultimate friendship story. Our protags are Bheem (N. T. Rama Rao Jr.) and Raju (Ram Charan), whose stories are given equal screen time, with one's being much more intricate than the other. Everything is over-the-top, from the cartoonishly evil villains (Ray Stevenson, Allison Doody, Edward Sonnenblick) to the use of exotic, wild animals as weapons. The tone is set when Raju engages in a Kill Bill-like fight scene to retrieve a malcontent from an angry mob. RRR arises out of "Tollywood," or the Telugu-language film center in Southern India. It is filled with song and dance, some more understandable than others. For instance, the "hook dance" scene moves along the plot, as the dance itself is a scene showing that the Indians can defeat the pretentious British in a dance-off. Other dance numbers seemed random and superfluous, merely padding an already extensive run-time. The side-story of Bheem and Jenny (Olivia Morris) was forced and merely inserted to show that not all of the white people were terrible. RRR is a spectacle of national pride and definitely does what movies of this grandiosity are meant to do: entertain.

While not a bad film by any stretch of the imagination RRR is nonetheless a bit overrated, by western standards at least. It’s a loud, bombastic, and colorful fable that is tuned to the particular tastes of.indian audiences. With 22 languages in India getting the emotional beats of a story across cannot depend on language or cultural norms. So when someone breaks into singing a sad song it doesn’t come across as jarring, you understand the point. On those terms RRR is a solid piece of entertainment that expertly weaves together it’s story beats. The trouble is that this is a limited form of drama because you take nuance off the table.

Because I have many problems with rrr
1) many action sequences were there that I didn't quite believe example: bhim and bike action scene in climax, And I have the same problems with Rajamouli's other films as well,example: Bahubali 2 palm tree scene 
I don't have any problem with over the top action sequences but some of scenes are very unconvincing for me,
( I didn't like these action scenes because of their choreography, And it is not that I dislike all the action scenes of RRR, I have also liked some of the action scenes of RRR, example=bheem introduction, interval fight scene, climax fight scene)
2) Rrr has the same stereotypical villain who we knew from the start that he is going to lose in the end,here I am talking about the character of the villain, I found the character of the villain very fake and cartoony,I did not feel any danger from it,The way he speaks the dialogues, it sounds fake,you can show cruelty in a better way like Tarantino did in inglorious bastards with Hans Landa, the way he delivers dialogues and manipulates people was mind-blowing, and another example was Leonardo DiCaprio in django unchained He was also a very cruel and over the top villain, but Leonardo DiCaprio's acting makes him a dangerous and unique antagonist ,He Really Feels Like A Direct Threat To Our Hero, and all this was missing in Rrr's villain,He never seems to be a direct threat to our heroes, I never thought that he would ever be able to defeat our heroes, in Bahubali bhallaldeva was very strong villain, that's why the Bettle of the last one seems very equal and interesting, but in rrr last Bettle was very well choreographed but it's very one-sided.
3)in the beginning of the movie people started thinking that Ram is antivillain but then after interval it was found that Ram is also against British, This was a surprising twist for many people but not for me because I recognized this as soon as I saw the trailer, I did not find it so surprising because a big movie superstar can never be a villain in India. That's why only after watching the trailer, I realized that Raju will also be against the British government. And yes raju and bhim's friendship happened by just an event i mean such a deep friendship may take time,A movie based on such friendship will be unique for America,but it is very common in India.
4) characters are to cartoony, Raju's character has some character development , But Bheem's character was very one-dimensional
RRR's characters lacks depth, 
This is the condition of commercial movies in India, they don't understand the importance of character's depth, they don't understand the importance of a good villain in the movie,
I could not connect with the characters,i could not connect with their friendship, I did not feel anything real in it. i need little bit of subtlety to connect with their bond more
I was not interested in the story and characters of the film because I have seen many such stories and characters many times in Indian cinema
5) honestly in some scenes Rrr's CGI was not good 
And I have problem with comedy in rrr, you will get to she this in many indian films that a desi boy falls in love with a foreign girl ,but our desi boy does not know how to speak English which creates comedy, whole name pronouncing thing was so lame and such an old trick to create comedy
Finally I don't hate rrr it's better than other trash Indian comercial films like pathaan, kgf and pushpa but I don't think that Rrr is the best movie of 2022

RRRidiculous

This is a truly weird movie. Fun, but weird. It's a wacky cross between Marvel and Bollywood.

RRR is very loosely based on actual events. Loose is an understatement. It's so loose that it is falling apart - apart from reality that is. 

A reviewer at RogerEbert.com describes British Governor Scott (played by Ray Stevenson) as a "cartoonishly evil" character. True enough, but that's because everyone and everything in the whole damned movie is cartoonish! Calling one character from this absurdity "cartoonish" is absurd. It's like singling out Elmer Fudd as "the funny animated one" from the "Looney Tunes" series.

I initially did not want to watch this because I feared that it would be like viewing a three hour video game (yes, it's running time is 3 hours and 7 minutes). But, since we have a Netflix subscription, and it was an offering, we decided to give it a try. I wasn't wrong about the video game fears. The film does have that look.

Surprisingly, we were not disappointed in the film's overall entertainment value. Actually, we were quite amused by all the insane scenes and we both frequently laughed out loud. 

But this raises the question, "Is RRR a comedy?" To be honest, I'm not sure. Every description I've read labels it a drama. But really? If the producers were looking for drama, then why frame your intended seriousness in the goofiest, craziest, wildest cinematic nonsense of the year?

Due to all of its rib-tickling silliness, I'm giving this movie a marginally positive rating. If it is not supposed to be funny, well, I'll recommend it anyway. Who doesn't need a good laugh these days?

This box office record-breaking Indian film, re-imagining real historical figures during India's fight for independence in the 1920s in a fictitious and epic story, is bombastic and unsubtle, contrived and ridiculously (over)plotted and somersaults from genre to genre in a whiplash-inducing manner, making haphazard detours into romcom, tragedy, war movies and prison break movies at various stages of its 3hrs+ duration; and I can't say I didn't enjoy the heck out of it on a mostly visceral level, and it's perfect for viewing on Netflix with pause button at hand. When a young village girl is taken away by a mean British governor's wife (cue pantomime hissing), NTR Jr's kind but extremely skillful tribal leader Komaram Bheem is sent to Delhi to bring her back. En route, he befriends, in an unequivocally homoerotic/platonic manner with an action drama equivalent of a romcom meet-cute, Ramm Charan Teja's ruthlessly determined Rama Raju who has his own secret agenda and is coincidentally tasked to hunt down Bheem, except initially, both are unaware of the other's true identity. With plot development constantly taking a backseat to logic and physics-defying action sequences that are nevertheless stupidly entertaining and musical numbers that bring the film and its momentum to a shuddering halt, S.S. Rajamouli's film is a cornucopia of pleasures and eyeball-rolling insanity. For every rousing and ingeniously choreographed piggyback fight sequence with Bheem carrying an injured Rama, there's an incredulous herbal remedy conveniently available to magically heal Rama allowing him to run in minutes; whilst ropey special effects with the animals are almost forgotten (and forgiven) after a dazzling display rescuing a child from a burning train or an impressively mounted, infectious and totally bonkers dance-off spectacle, which in and of itself perfectly encapsulates a film this brazenly mainstream, manipulative and maximalist.

The creativity that RRR has to offer, is something I have never seen before until now, the stunt coordinators did a incredible job, at keeping the fights interesting and impactful. RRR sure has some flaws, the VFX are not always the greatest and i thought that the over use of low framerate slow-motion was a bit overdown, however those things come with the package of a Bollywood film and they give the movie their own identity. The dance sequences were so much fun to watch, with everybody giving it their all. I must give my compliments as well to the stunt guys, you guys really did some fenemonal stunts and took a lot of risks doing them. Overall RRR is a refreshing movie, something that Hollywood would never do and something that has made so many people around the world incredibly happy!

We all know Indian films are over the top, but this..................
This film just knows soooooooo well how to indulge. It takes the idea that cinema is something grand, something you've never seen before and will probably never see again and it just runs with it. It's an epic, it's an action/adventure, it's a musical, it's a comedy, it's literally everything. Everything can be bigger, everything can be grander, everything can be louder, everything can be more fun, and this film is absolute embodiment of that. Whatever you do, just do yourself a favour and watch it.

RRR goes for broke in every direction imaginable. It is utterly unselfconscious cinema that is reminding audiences worldwide the kind of revelatory experience that can be achieved when we leave our irony at the door. 

The two leads, N. T. Rama Rao Jr. and Ram Charan - as veritable superhuman forces, Bheem and Raju - are exceptional. Switching between comedy and drama, action and dance - and performing every single task absolutely exquisitely. Ram also happens to be one of the most beautiful human beings - man or woman - that I have yet come across on my travels. 

I expected to be held at more of a distance by cultural idiosyncrasies (this being my first ever film from India) but everything felt surprisingly universal - from the themes to the relationships and the operatic displays of action and emotion. The eyebrow raising nationalism that quietly crept in (and then loudly declared itself during the final number) is also, sadly, pretty universal and I found myself start to nervously sober up once the flags started flying across the screen.

However, as a cinematic experience the film is a shining light and a true joy to experience.

As a big fan of Bahubali 1, and an even bigger fan of Bahubali 2, I had a lot of expectations going into RRR. I wasn't expecting another magnum opus, but I was expecting a gripping story, replete with incredible screenplay, clever action sequences and a fair share of twists and turns in the plot. RRR fails to deliver on all counts.

I don't even know where to begin. Rajamouli takes too much time introducing the protagonists - the Fire and the Water analogies are meaningless and poorly concocted. One cannot but help wonder if all that wasted time in the movie could not have been used to develop a more interesting plot. The protagonists themselves are so bad in every respect that I can't even remember their character names in the movie. Compare that to the like Kattappa and Bhalla and Sivakami in Bahubali or even the relentless Fly in Naan Eee, and you soon run out of leeway. There is a weak attempt at justifying underdeveloped ideologies for the two main archetypes in the movie, and it is so poorly developed that it fails to hit the spot.

The plot meanders along aimlessly from one boring scene to another, with random characters weaving in and out like caricatures in a bad comic book. There is a scene where NTR gets to take a crack at a cop who unnecessarily roughs him up in an earlier sequence. Knowing Rajamouli, I was expecting more impact in that scene, but it was so predictable and poorly delivered, that it failed to leave any impression whatsoever.

There is an even weaker attempt in the movie at rekindling a romance, which goes nowhere - neither is it interesting, nor is it likeable. And the flashbacks are pathetic attempts to justify pointless ideologies that they are only a distraction in the movie, and best forgotten sooner rather than later. Characters like Ajay Devgn and Alia Bhatt have been thoroughly wasted, as are Shriya Sarin and Samuthrakani.

The music is ok, and the cinematography is ok, but the most important ingredient in any movie, the lowest common denominator, so to speak, is the story and the plot, and as hard as he has tried to piece something together in RRR, Rajamouli has failed miserably.

In sum, I would not recommend wasting your time on this movie. I hope the director finds his way again, and makes a compelling comeback in his next flick.

What a story! What a spectacle! This movie is a remarkable achievement for Indian action cinema, and for primarily one reason of the uttermost importance: it seamlessly mixes very classical, Shakespearean plot with mind-bending, incredibly creative action scenes that are made with skill and imagination becoming of artisans whose dwellings are no lower than at Mont Parnassus. Neither of those two are praiseworthy on their own – without the story "RRR" would be an empty action flick more akin to what Marvel and DC do in the US, and without the action will become a dull and overly simplistic period piece more akin to an umpteenth re-edition on "Ben-Hur". But this movie has both and they work, God, how they work to make this movie the best it could possibly be. Only at places (especially at the ending) it becomes too didactic and the viewer is reminded that it is also, at least in the smallest part, a propaganda piece, even if it states at the very beginning that it does not intend to be so. Forget that though, "RRR" is perhaps THE cinematic event of the year and you would be hard-pressed to find anyone who would event attempt to say otherwise.

After hearing this movie is spectacular from all over the Internet, I decided to give it a shot. I will admit that I am not a huge fan of musicals and while I do love a good action movie, extremely over the top is something that is a turn off to me. Having said that RRR is a well made movie. That is the only praise that I can get it. The story is generic, which isn't too much of a strike against it. There are a lot of stories out there that have been repeated over and over again. The issue that I have with this movie is the extreme nature of the action. I do love a good over the top action movie but, there is something about how it's done that resonates more than anything else. Instead of coming off insanely awesome, the action seems more of a borderline parody. I had the same issue with the recent Fast and Furious 9. This movie comes off more like a live action cartoon, which can be extremely offputting. If you need a sense of groundedness to your action movies, this is not the movie for you. Overall, there are some moments that really do make the movie enchanting but for me those are few and far between.

Hollywood should be taking notes.  So this is a fictitious story about two legendary revolutionaries (N.T. Rama Rao Jr., Ram Charan Teja) in India in the 1920s.  Their paths are on a collision course, but will they emerge as friends or foes?  Now I typically don't watch a whole lot of Bollywood.  It's for the same reason that I haven't gotten into all that much anime: the library is so extensive that I don't know the best place to start.  With RRR, however, too many of the right people have been saying the right things about it.  Perhaps it has something to do with it being the most expensive Indian movie ever produced, but regardless, I decided to give it a watch on the last day of my vacation.  After all, three hours is a pretty tall commitment, so what better time to watch than a day with no obligations?  RRR may take up a large portion of your day, but pound for pound, this is about the most bang you will ever get for your buck when it comes to watching a movie.  RRR is ridiculous in the best way possible.  Yes, it's outlandish, but it's honestly not that far off from the very best Marvel movies, with the only difference being that they aren't spelling out that these two guys have superpowers.  You will know exactly the kind of movie you are watching by the time you get to the title card.  Granted, that's at the 40-minute mark, but it's a wildly entertaining opening.  What I love about this movie is that it knows that it needs to keep topping itself.  Because they are aware of that, it keeps escalating, and it keeps your engagement heightened.  That makes it so you don't care about the extended runtime.  I'm not usually a fan of movies being this long, but there are always exceptions.  Personally, I took a couple of mini-breaks during the act shifts, but I was always excited to pick it right back up again.  This is a movie that kind of has it all.  Obviously, if you've watched a trailer or the autoplay Netflix bumper, you know that they have action covered, but there is also comedy, romance, singing, and expertly executed dance numbers.  What more could you ask for?  I only have a couple of minor quibbles for RRR.  I don't think the CGI on the animals is the best you've ever seen, but that might be for the best because they do some pretty crazy stunts with them, and nobody wants to see an animal in peril.  I wasn't the biggest fan of the English actors in this.  I'm not sure if S.S. Rajamouli is just better at directing people who speak Telugu, but the majority of the white actors felt like Imperial officers from Star Wars for the majority of this.  That said, these are pretty minor flaws, and I'm not going to hold it against this hugely enjoyable experience.  There's a solid chance that this will get promoted to a five-star movie if I give it a second watch, and let me tell you: I highly desire to watch this again.

While it was a long movie, the numerous plots converged into one massive hit that is RRR. Seeing something so outlandish, fun and action-packed was refreshing while trying not to be too serious about itself. I think if it were too serious, the depiction of British rule in India would have met backlash or not lend itself to a wider worldwide audience. It wanted to depict the struggles of being under colonial rule, as well as marrying depictions of well-known characters and gods in their culture. While some may find this to be nonsensical, especially the action scenes, personally, I think this was a benefit, because the British rule was harsh and cruel, and this may be harder for the wider audience to stomach. The costume design, set design and actor choice were impeccable. While the storyline was 3 hours long, it was gripping throughout! The multiple storylines created emotion as well as story and character development that was fulfilling. The FX used lent itself well to the outlandish nature of the movie, and used only during action scenes or montages. The music and dance used in the film was fantastic and fun, providing moments of relief and highlighting the relationships between the characters.
A true masterpiece with bunch of emotions and bromance. #RRRforoscars

Adrenaline filled entertainment at its absolute best. I haven't really branched out into Tollywood or Bollywood films before and this was an amazing introduction. I love that the over the top action had an actual purpose to it, and it wasn't just there for the sake of being there. For example, the introduction to Bheem's character of him catching a tiger was there to not only make him look cool but capturing the tiger actually had a purpose that was paid off later in the movie. All of the dramatic and over the top moments in this movie are like that; they are there for entertainment purposes but they also serve the overall story, and this is why I think this movie works so well. It was a perfect example of using crazy sequences in order to create better storytelling. I didn't mind the over the top moments because without them this story wouldn't have been as good and I wouldn't have cared about it as much. The movie made me love the two lead characters because it made them seem so cool and heroic, and this was thanks to the dramatic action and moments. The story is also massive and well thought out, and it has something for everybody to enjoy. This movie just made me so happy and I loved every minute of it.

This film is wild. Like a true Bollywood epic it is over-the-top in every way, but it has a huge heart. This one, however, adds deep allegory, mythological/religious themes, historical context, and the most mind-blowing fight scenes. It's just amazing. Typical Indian movie for the times. Nothing new with the exaggerated and super fake fighting scenes and the extremely overdone and predictable from beginning to end plot. I love Ram Charan but even having him and some of the other important characters trying to make this a half decent movie doesn't change the fact we've seen this type of movie hundreds of times now. Make more interesting movies with better writing and maybe possibly, hopefully with a bit more believable fights that aren't so ridiculously inhuman that it just makes you scoff at how dumb it is. I'm hoping that this fake and unbelievable fighting that started with dabanng will end very soon because it just makes people cringe more than anything now. There also needs to be work done on making the story better and less predictable then what we've been getting everyday for the past decade or more now.

I absolutely loved the 3 hours I spent watching RRR. It took me a while to get to it because the run time seemed daunting but I am glad that I finally carved out time to watch it. RRR is over the top and ridiculous in all of the best ways. The visuals, action, dancing, all of it - A++. 

My only minor gripe would be that the plot was easy to figure out. It was not ground breaking by any means and it was clear to figure out what the "twist" was. This did not detract from my enjoyment of RRR at all, but if I had to find one thing to critique, this would be it.

Overall, I really enjoyed RRR. It was unlike anything I've ever watched and I am excited to explore more Indian cinema. Many thanks to Straw Hat Goofy for recommending this one on TikTok.

Weird that people either hate or love this thing.  'RRR' gets points in the West for just plain not being like anything else.  I feel like a missed much of this film as I suspect a lot of it is common Bollywood trope, and there were a bunch of cultural and political references that I had no clue about.  The film them proceeds to be as whacked out as possible, as if Hunter S Thompson was filming Indian history.  The narrative and battle scenes made zero sense and were completely implausible.  I guess fine if you are making a cartoon, which is basically what this film is, replete with mustache twirling British baddies.  I found myself fast forwarding through the 'action' scenes to get to the maudlin dialogue.
All that said, the cinematography, visuals and stunts are impressive, and I thought the bromance worked pretty well.  I especially liked the Raju cop character.

RRR ended up being one of the biggest Indian movies for many obvious reasons. This is an astonishing spectacle of epic storytelling, incredible technical craftsmanship and a typically Indian, highly enjoyable cocktail of different genres put together into a messy, but eclectic mix. The immense silliness of its action sequences was downright ridiculous and frequently quite dumb, but there is no denying that the movie is hugely entertaining and never boring, which is an impressive accomplishment given its staggering three-hour runtime. The main bromance and the infusion of Indian Mythological elements into a period piece were the two standouts plotwise while the movie's big heart and electrifying performances from its two stars were its biggest selling points.

Wasn't sure what to expect going into the movie, but man, 10 minutes in and I was sold! Epic action sequences and a good story that grabs you and draws you in for the entire length.  It was like watching Michael Bay and Baz Luhrman make a movie together.  It is not for everyone, but if you wanna be entertained for 3 hours, I would recommend it!
It's a mixture of all blockbusters movies together. Have everything from dance number to action, romance and bromance. Absolutely loving it.

Please see this fabulous film!
This is a very entertaining movie! It has it all, the history, the action, the sorrow, the laughter, and the romance! Great actors! Action packed 3 hours. True enjoyment!
It's action, it's heart, it's one of my favorite movies of the year! Yes, it is long..BUT WORTH IT! Everything is answered by the end and you will laugh and cry! SEE THIS MOVIE!

From the perspective of a white Londoner, I cannot emphasize how much this film rules.

The most expensive Indian film produced to date at the time of its release, RRR is a mega-blockbuster that uses heavily fictionalized accounts of famed Indian independence leaders as inspiration for an buddy-action epic with exuberance and creativity in that uniquely Bollywood style. I imagine the rough American equivalent would be if Ben Franklin and George Washington teamed up in their younger years for a dash of revolutionary guerrilla warfare, but there's no way a Hollywood studio would be able to make that work. 

S. S. Rajamouli creates a sweeping film that is less concerned with the tightness of its writing (and certainly not with realism) as it is the visual spectacle; while the quality of the CG might not be up to the standard of other big-budget productions, RRR makes up for it largely with its willingness to use it in creative ways. In this director's world, emotion is the standard currency, so if we want a joyful dance-off between our two protagonists (who are again, real-life Indian revolutionaries) against an entire British garden party, we'll get one. With leads as charismatic as Ram Charan and Jr NTR, this script conveys just as much about male friendship as it does about the Indian struggle against the British Raj. Representative of quite a bit of what is distinctive and enjoyable about Indian film. (3.5/5)

I usually don't dig Bollywood movies that were too over-the-top, which is like most Bollywood movies. However, I gotta give it to RRR for making it actually fun and exciting.

Horrendous CGI aside, the dance scenes were super dope, especially that dance battle. Me and my boy actually wanted to give the dance a try. It won't be that good, but the point is that the actors were damn entertaining and amazing executing those moves. 

The action scenes were just as badass. It's so hilariously ridiculous and stupid that I loved it. It's basically a superhero movie. The two actors were also the important part that made these scenes entertaining. 

The story itself was not bad, even though it dragged so much during the middle part. I was bored for a good chunk, waiting for more action scenes. The backstories didn't really add much to the present plot, even though they provided some more fun action. And of course, I didn't feel any emotional connection to any of the characters, as I just wanted this movie to be all about the over-the-top action.

Overall, it's a highly entertaining movie that I had a great time even though there's still many problems with it. 7.5/10
